message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="STV: Foreword and/or Translator's Preface">
NEW VOTE (replaces previous): Front matter structure for the English edition.

The author may write a Preface later — that's separate. For now, we're deciding about the Foreword and Translator's Preface.

Three options:
A. **Foreword only** (written by an outside scholar/figure)
B. **Foreword + Translator's Preface** (both)
C. **Translator's Preface only** (no foreword)

SINGLE TRANSFERABLE VOTE. Rank all three:

"1st: [A/B/C] — 2nd: [A/B/C] — 3rd: [A/B/C] — Reason: [brief justification]"
</teammate-message>

input.content: 1st: C — 2nd: B — 3rd: A — Reason: The translator's preface is non-negotiable -- it must explain the Jing transliteration, the -scape system, the performative/experimental dimension of the essays, and the terminological departures from standard philosophical translations. Without it, English readers will misread the collection. A foreword by an outside scholar is a nice-to-have but carries risks: (1) it interposes an interpretive authority between the author and reader before the reader has encountered the work, which cuts against the collection's own insistence that understanding must be experientially constructed by the reader themselves (my Analysis Report, S2 -- the essays are philosophical experiments that work on the reader directly); (2) finding the right scholar is non-trivial -- the work spans Chinese philosophy, category theory, phenomenology, existentialism, and philosophy of language, so any single foreword writer will inevitably frame the collection through their own tradition's lens, potentially biasing the reader's first encounter. Option B is acceptable if a truly cross-disciplinary scholar can be found, but Option A alone (foreword without translator's preface) would leave the terminological apparatus unexplained, which is unacceptable.
input.summary: Vote: C first, B second, A third

routing.summary: Vote: C first, B second, A third

content.text: Vote submitted. Awaiting next instructions from the team lead.
